p.s: John Worne employs various strategies and techniques to convince the reader of the presented opinion.
Generally he makes use of a formal register, as is seen for instance in the passage any prospect of us re-commissioning out collective brains (l. 5).
As the reader is expected to know what a GCSE (l. 8) is, it is clear that the article is addressed primarily to well-educated British citizens.
Informal register however is employed as wel, e.g. Cobblers (l. 15), in order to connect the issue closer to the readerships everyday life.
The author gives examples for his arguments (cf. ll. 9-11, 28f.) and quotes the CBI/Pearson Education and Skills Survey (l. 19) to back his position up with further evidence.
Worne repeats the word languages (ll. 2, 4, 6, 11, 16, 17, 20) many times to stress the issue.

He also combines his line of argument with vivid descriptions such as you may crash or choke on the roaming data charges (l. 14) and makes use of the ironic hyperbole wearable tech will enable intercultural telepathy anyway in order to attract the readersreader's attention.
For the same reason and to create a common identity part of the readership is directly addressed towards the end of the article so, parents of the UK (and I am one) (l. 30).
As he aforementioned repetition enumerations also empasizeemphasize certain aspects.
In the case of languages are essential for out trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and national security (ll. 17f.) this is the importance of language learning.
To conclude it can be said that Worne presents his view in a proffessionalyprofessionally and convincing manner, also by refferingreferring to his opponentsopponents' arguments.
